title: 112_hr2252
content: The Act may be cited as the "Citizens' Self-Defense Act of 2011". The Congress finds that police are not legally liable for failing to protect individual citizens, as courts have ruled that their duty is only to the public in general. Former Florida Attorney General Jim Smith also acknowledged this. The Congress finds that police are not legally liable for failing to protect individual citizens, as courts have ruled that their duty is only to the public in general. Former Florida Attorney General Jim Smith acknowledged that police responded to only a fraction of calls for help. Additionally, the United States Department of Justice found a high number of crimes of violence in 1989 for which police had not responded promptly. Citizens often resort to using firearms to defend themselves, with over 2,400,000 people in the United States using a gun for self-defense annually. Every year, over 2,400,000 people in the United States use guns for self-defense, with 92% only brandishing or firing warning shots. Of these cases, more than 192,000 are women defending against sexual abuse. Firearms are used 60 times more to protect lives than to take them. In 2001, a grand jury ruled on the case of 2 brothers who used firearms to protect themselves and their business from burglaries in Reisterstown, Maryland. The grand jury decided not to press criminal charges against them. The grand jury in Reisterstown, Maryland decided not to press criminal charges against two brothers who shot and killed a burglar and injured two others at their concrete business. The brothers had encountered several burglaries and spent the night armed with shotguns in their warehouse. The injured men were charged with burglary, along with two others connected to previous break-ins at the warehouse. The brothers were concerned about the violence of burglary, especially after realizing a gun had been stolen in a previous break-in. In 2008, a store clerk in Waukegan, Illinois shot and injured a robber, potentially facing criminal charges for not having a firearm owner's identification card. Illinois law prohibits employees from carrying guns in a place of business unless they are the owner or have proprietary interest. In September 2009, a Lithonia homeowner from Dekalb County, Georgia, was charged with aggravated assault for shooting someone attempting to break into his home. The robber was not inside the home at the time. In January 2004, a Wilmette, Illinois homeowner was charged with misdemeanors for owning handguns and violating the village handgun ban ordinance after shooting a home intruder. The resident faced fines for not renewing his firearm owner's identification card. The homeowner had a Plan A to call 911 and keep the family safe, but also had a Plan B to use a loaded firearm against an intruder. The intruder entered the house twice, once through a dog door and the second time with a stolen key. The homeowner confronted and shot the intruder, who then stole the family's car to go to the hospital. The intruder was charged with residential burglary and possession of a stolen vehicle. Police officers have been granted immunity for using firearms in the line of duty. The homeowner shot an intruder who entered the house twice, leading to charges of residential burglary and possession of a stolen vehicle. Courts have granted immunity to police officers using firearms in duty, and law-abiding citizens should not face lawsuits for using firearms in self-defense. The right to obtain firearms for security and use them in defense of self, family, or home is protected by law. The right to obtain firearms for security and use them in defense of self, family, or home is reaffirmed for individuals not prohibited by law. This includes using firearms in defense against imminent serious bodily harm, during a violent felony, or in defense of one's home during a felony. The term "firearm" is defined as a shotgun, rifle, or handgun. A person whose firearm rights are violated can bring a legal action for damages and other relief. The court may award attorney's fees to the prevailing plaintiff. The court may award attorney's fees to the prevailing plaintiff in an action brought under paragraph (1) for damages and relief. An action under paragraph (1) must be brought within 5 years of discovering the violation.
